texts.content_text1: Before you get to the lecture, let's worm up and have a guess:
texts.content_text100: Children’s personal data requires special protection because children are considered legally and socially vulnerable.
texts.content_text300: Children are recognised as vulnerable individuals whose data requires heightened safeguards under international and EU law.
texts.content_text101: Data protection is mainly an administrative issue and not a fundamental rights issue.
texts.content_text301: Privacy and data protection are recognised as fundamental rights, not merely administrative or technical matters.
texts.content_text102: The GDPR contains specific provisions addressing the processing of children’s personal data.
texts.content_text302: The GDPR explicitly includes rules and safeguards concerning the lawful processing of children’s data.
texts.content_text103: Lawyers only need to follow legal rules when representing children, not ethical standards.
texts.content_text303: Lawyers are bound by both legal obligations and professional ethical standards when representing children.
texts.content_text104: Protecting children’s personal data is only the responsibility of courts.
texts.content_text304: The responsibility extends to states, legal professionals, institutions, and anyone processing children’s data.
texts.content_text105: International law recognises a child’s right to privacy.
texts.content_text305: The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child explicitly recognises children’s right to privacy.
